content: I don't think it's fair to assume that players know the rules of chess and values of chess pieces in a reverse mode. Especially since the "values" are pretty much arbitrary and sometimes different values are used (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chess_piece_relative_value#Alternative_valuations).

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very good contribution and easy to solve!
Good for intermediates and medium for beginners.
Edit: Can be good for shortest mode.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This I think easy but it can be better by working on it.

This is easy enough to solve as a chess player, but I'm not sure if this would be solvable for someone who has never played Chess and doesn't understand that pawns are weakest and Queens are strongest. It might be too hard to reverse engineer without the prior knowledge of chess.

I feel like I can't give an unbiased opinion on whether this clash is appropriate for Reverse as a chess player, but hopefully some non-players give this a go and can see if it is solvable for them. The test case names make it clear it is chess, so I guess worst case scenario they could Google "queen chess value" and start to confirm their hunch..

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good proposition
The names of the actual pieces are Pawn, Knight, Bishop, Rook, Queen and King.

I find this clash very well put together. Step by step, you can quickly guess the value of the points for each letter. Solving it is quite quick, you just have to find all the rules.

Note that in reverse mode, the display is different from that in the test phase. In reverse mode, you can easily see all the tests.
This clash is about the value of pieces in chess. People who don’t play chess will find this more difficult.
This clash is quite challenging for reverse mode.

The testcases are supposed to be very progressive, with a testcase that gives the value of P, a testcase that gives the value of B, etc, so even someone who doesn't know what the letters stand for should be able to piece it together.

I don't assume that at all. The testcases have been chosen specifically to tell the players what the values are. If you really didn't know chess you could even solve this problem without even recognising that it is related to chess.
